The information from this self assessment will be used to monitor your current health status so try to choose most accurate answer. The information will be also used for monitoring and management of current health crisis and research in our fight against corona

"Which of the following apply to you? "
How do I take care of someone who\'s quarantined in my home?
✔\t Help the person who is sick follow their doctor’s instructions for care and medicine.For most people, symptoms last a few days, and people usually feel better after a week.
✔\t See if over-the-counter medicines for fever help the person feel better.
✔\t Make sure the person who is sick drinks a lot of fluids and rests.
✔\t Help them with grocery shopping, filling prescriptions, and getting other items they may need. Consider having the items delivered through a delivery service, if possible.
✔\t Take care of their pet(s), and limit contact between the person who is sick and their pet(s) when possible.
✔\t Call their doctor if the person keeps getting sicker. Limit contact with the patient and do not share personal items.
✔\t tClean your hands regularly.
WHEN TO SEEK FOR MEDICAL HELP?
If someone is showing any of these signs, seek emergency medical care immediately:
✔\t Trouble breathing
✔\t Persistent pain or pressure in the chest
✔\t New confusion
✔\t Inability to wake or stay awake
✔\t Bluish lips or face
⭐\t This list is not all the possible symptoms. Please call your medical provider for any other symptoms that are severe or concerning to you.

✔\t Patients with confirmed COVID-19 should remain under home isolation precautions until the risk of secondary transmission to others is thought to be low. The decision to discontinue home isolation precautions is made on a case-by-case basis, in consultation with health care providers, and state and local health departments.

"✔\t People who are placed under active monitoring or facilitated self-monitoring should follow instructions provided by their local health department or occupational health professionals, as appropriate. "
✔\t Please contact your local or state health department as soon as possible in case of any emergency or irregularities in health

✔\t Do not share dishes, drinking glasses, cups, eating utensils, towels or bedding with other people or pets in your home. After using these items, they should be washed thoroughly with soap and water.
"✔\t Clean all high-touch surfaces daily which include counters, tabletops, doorknobs, bathroom fixtures, toilets, phones, keyboards, tablets, and bedside tables. "
✔\t Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.

✔\t Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or clean your hands with an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains 60 to 95% alcohol, covering all surfaces of your hands and rubbing them together until they feel dry.
✔\t Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when you cough or sneeze. Throw used tissues in a lined trash can.
"✔\t Always wear a face mask when you are around other people (e.g., sharing a room or vehicle) or pets, and before you enter a health care provider’s office. "
✔\t If you have a medical appointment, call the health care provider prior to your appointment and tell them that you have symptoms of COVID.
✔\t Separate yourself from people and animals at home.

✔\t Restrict activities outside your home, except for getting medical care. Under no circumstance you should go to work, school, or public areas. Avoid using public transportation, ride sharing, or taxis.
Taking a hot bath DOES NOT prevent the coronavirus.
Cold weather and snow CANNOT kill the CoronaVirus .
There is NO evidence that companion animals/pets such as dogs or \t\tcats can transmit the coronavirus.
The coronavirus CANNOT be transmitted through mosquito bites.
Hand dryers are NOT effective in killing the coronavirus.
Ultraviolet light SHOULD NOT be used for sterilization and can cause skin irritation.
Spraying alcohol or chlorine all over your body WILL NOT kill viruses that have already entered your body.
Antibiotics DO NOT work against viruses, antibiotics only work against bacteria.
To date, there is NO specific medicine recommended to prevent or treat the coronavirus.
Thermal scanners CAN detect if people have a fever but CANNOT detect whether or not someone has the coronavirus.
Vaccines against pneumonia, such as pneumococcal vaccine and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine, DO NOT provide \t\tprotection against the coronavirus.
There is NO evidence that regularly rinsing the nose with saline has protected people from infection with the coronavirus.
Garlic is healthy but there is NO evidence from the current outbreak that eating garlic has protected people from the coronavirus.
The coronavirus CAN be transmitted in areas with hot and humid climates.
LONG LASTING FRESH FUITS AND VEGETABLES
✔\t WHO recommends consuming a minimum of 400g of fruits and vegetables per day such as citrus fruits,root vegetables etc
LIMIT YOUR SALT INTAKE:
✔\t WHO recommends consuming less than 5g of salt per day.
LIMIT YOUR FAT INTAKE
CONSUME ENOUGH FIBRE
STAY HYDRATED
AVOID ALCOHOLCONSUMPTION
AVOID SMOKING
FROZEN FRUITS AND VEGETABLES
REDUCED-FAT,SHELF-STABLE MILK
DRIED FRUITS, NUTS AND SEEDS
EGGS
✔\t WHO recommends that ideally less than 5% of total energy intake for adults
✔\t WHO recommends limiting total fat intake to less than 30% of total energy intake,of which no more than 10% should come from the saturated fat.
✔\t Fibre offers prolonged feeling of fullness,which prevents overeating.To ensure an adequate fibre intake,aim to include vegetables,fruits,wholegrain food like rice,oats,quinoa etc.
✔\t Good hydration is crucial for optimal health.Avoid drinking large amount of strong coffee,strong tea and carbonated drinks.Try drinking hot/warm water and do not take cold water.

✔\t Alcohol weakens immune system thus its heavy use undermines your body’s ability to cope with infectious disease,including COVID-19.It makes medications less effective,while increasing the potency and toxicity of others.Do not consume alcohol in combination with pain medication as it will interfere with liver function and might cause serious problems including liver failure.
✔\t It makes the immune system of an individual weaker and increases the probability to become more prone to diseases.
✔\t All frozen vegetables are great option as contain high level of fibre and vitamins.
✔\t Beans,chickpeas,lentils and other pulses are great source of vegetable protein,fibre,vitamins and minerals.

✔\t Dairy products provide an inexpensive source of protein and other nutrients.Choosing reduced-fat dairy is one way to reduce saturated fat consumption.UHT milk in a can or carton will be relatively shelf-stable.Powdered milk is another shelf-stable option.
✔\t Particularly unsweetened and unsalted,these may serve as healthy snack or added to porridge,salads or other meals.
✔\t They are a great source of protein and nutrients and are incredibly versatile.Opt for boiling or poached rather than frying.
Do\'s
Dont\'s
✔\t Regularly and thoroughly clean your hands with an alcohol-based hand rub or wash them with soap and water.
✔\t Avoid going to crowded places.
✔\t Avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth. .
✔\t Stay home and self-isolate even with minor symptoms such as cough, headache, mild fever, until you recover.
✔\t Cover your mouth and nose with a mask when around others.
✔\t Avoid unnecessary travelling.

✔\t Boost your immune system. Boosting your immune system can really help you here; with fresh food like veggies and fruits, involving oneself in indoor exercises, intake of essential nutrients like Vitamin B12 with Methylcobalamin, Magnesium etc.
✔\t To throw used tissues into closed bins immediately after use.
✔\t Use separate bedding and towels and not share these with other household members.
✔\t If water is not available,use hand sanitizer with atleast 60% alcohol.
1.\tEat a brain-healthy diet to support strong mental health

An unhealthy diet can take a toll on your brain and mood, disrupt your sleep, sap your energy, and weaken your immune system. Conversely, switching to a wholesome diet, low in sugar and rich in healthy fats, can give you more energy, improve your sleep and mood.
Foods that adversely affect mood
✔\t Caffeine
✔\t Alcohol
✔\t Trans fats or anything with “partially hydrogenated” oil
✔\t Foods with high levels of chemical preservatives or hormones
✔\t Sugary snacks
✔\t Refined carbs such as white rice or white flour
✔\t Fried food
Foods that boost mood
✔\t Fatty fish rich in Omega-3s such as salmon, herring, mackerel, anchovies, sardines, tuna
✔\t Nuts such as walnuts, almonds, cashews, peanuts
✔\t Avocados
✔\t Flaxseed
✔\t Beans
✔\t Leafy greens such as spinach, kale, Brussel’s sprouts
✔\t Fresh fruit such as blueberries
2.Manage emotions to relieve stress:
"✔\t Understanding and accepting your emotions—especially those unpleasant ones many of us try to ignore—can make a huge difference in your ability to manage stress and balance your moods. "
3.Talk about your feelings:
✔\t Talking about your feelings can help you stay in good mental health and deal with times when you feel troubled.
4.Drink sensibly:

✔\t We often drink alcohol to change our mood. Some people drink to deal with fear or loneliness, but the effect is only temporary.When the drink wears off, you feel worse. Drinking is not a good way to manage difficult feelings.
5.Do something you’re good at:
✔\t What do you love doing? What activities can you lose yourself in? What did you love doing in the past? Enjoying yourself can help beat stress
6.Accept who you are:
✔\t We’re all different. It’s much healthier to accept that you’re unique than to wish you were more like someone else. Feeling good about yourself boosts your confidence.
7. Ask for help:

✔\t No one is a superhuman. We all sometimes get tired or overwhelmed by how we feel or when things don’t go to plan. If things are getting too much for you and you feel you can’t cope, ask for help from your family or friends.
"Note:- Our recommended diet plan is exclusively designed on the basis of your answers asked during the self-assessment Test. If you allergic to any of the food items please do not intake them. "
